what: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends
title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends
text: repository contains R package phtt estimating panel data models generalize classical fixed effects models allow control time varying individual fixed effects. readable introduction panel data models, estimation inference procedures package described Bada, O., & Liebl, D. (2014). phtt: Panel Data Analysis Heterogeneous Time Trends R. Journal Statistical Software, 59(6), 1–33. https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v059.i06 Free Download paper (PDF):

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends
text: R package phtt contains three main functions. Bai, J. (2009). Panel data models interactive fixed effects. Econometrica, 77(4), 1229-1279. refined estimation version described Bada, O., & Kneip, . (2014). Parameter cascading panel models unknown number unobserved factors: application credit spread puzzle. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 76, 95-115. Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., & Song, W. (2012). new panel data treatment heterogeneity time trends. Econometric theory, 28(3), 590-628. OptDim() function contains implementations many different procedure estimating dimension unobserved factor structure.

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends
Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends
text: following R codes reproduce figures article: Bada, O., & Liebl, D. (2014). phtt: Panel Data Analysis Heterogeneous Time Trends R. Journal Statistical Software, 59(6), 1–33. https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v059.i06
code:
## Load package library("phtt")  ## Load Data data("Cigar", package = "phtt") n <- 46 T <- 30 ## Dependent variable: Cigarette-Sales per Capita l.Consumption <- log(matrix(Cigar$sales, T, n)) ## Independent variables: Consumer Price Index cpi <- matrix(Cigar$cpi, T, n) ## Real Price per Pack of Cigarettes l.Price <- log(matrix(Cigar$price, T, n)/cpi) ## Real Disposable Income per Capita l.Income <- log(matrix(Cigar$ndi, T, n)/cpi)  ## ############################################################## ## Figure 1: ## ############################################################## scl <- 1.6 par(mfrow = c(1, 3), mar = c(6, 5, 5, 2.1)) matplot(l.Consumption, type = "l", main = "Log's of
Cigar-Consumption", ylab = "",    xlab = "Time", cex.main = scl, cex.lab = scl, cex.axis = scl) matplot(l.Price, type = "l", main = "Log's of
real Prices", ylab = "", xlab = "Time",    cex.main = scl, cex.lab = scl, cex.axis = scl) matplot(l.Income, type = "l", main = "Log's of
real Income", ylab = "", xlab = "Time",    cex.main = scl, cex.lab = scl, cex.axis = scl) par(mfrow = c(1, 1), mar = c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))  ## ############################################################## ## Estimation of the KSS model ## ############################################################## Cigar.KSS <- KSS(formula = l.Consumption ~ l.Price + l.Income) (Cigar.KSS.summary <- summary(Cigar.KSS))  ## ############################################################## ## Figure 2: ## ############################################################## plot(Cigar.KSS.summary)  ## Estimation of the number of factors OptDim(Obj = l.Consumption, criteria = "PC1")  (OptDim.obj <- OptDim(Obj = l.Consumption, criteria = c("PC3", "ER", "GR", "IPC1",    "IPC2", "IPC3"), standardize = TRUE))  ## ############################################################## ## Figure 3: ## ############################################################## plot(OptDim.obj)  ## This is for interactive use. ## KSS(formula = l.Consumption ~ -1 + l.Price + l.Income, consult.dim = TRUE)  ## First differences of the data: d.l.Consumption <- diff(l.Consumption) d.l.Price       <- diff(l.Price) d.l.Income      <- diff(l.Income)  ## ############################################################## ## Estimation of the EUP model ## ############################################################## (Cigar.Eup <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income, dim.criterion = "PC3")) summary(Cigar.Eup)  ## ############################################################## ## Figure 4: ## ############################################################## plot(summary(Cigar.Eup))   ## ############################################################## ## Estimation of the KSS model with additive individual effects ## ############################################################## Cigar2.KSS <- KSS(formula = l.Consumption ~ l.Price + l.Income, additive.effects = "individual") (Cigar2.KSS.summary <- summary(Cigar2.KSS))  ## ############################################################## ## Figure 5: ## ############################################################## scl <- 1.75 par(mar = c(6, 5, 5, 2.1)) plot(Cigar2.KSS.summary, cex.main = 1.25, cex.lab = scl, cex.axis = scl) par(mar = c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))   ## ############################################################## ## Testing for model specification ## ############################################################## twoways.obj     <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income, factor.dim = 0,    additive.effects = "twoways") not.twoways.obj <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income, factor.dim = 2,    additive.effects = "none") try(checkSpecif(obj1 = twoways.obj, obj2 = not.twoways.obj, level = 0.01))   Eup.obj <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income, additive.effects = "twoways") checkSpecif(Eup.obj, level = 0.01)  KSS.obj <- KSS(l.Consumption ~ -1 + l.Price + l.Income, additive.effects = "twoways") checkSpecif(KSS.obj, level = 0.01)  ## Percentages of explained variances coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Var.shares.of.loadings.param[1] coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Var.shares.of.loadings.param[2] coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Var.shares.of.loadings.param[3] coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Var.shares.of.loadings.param[4] coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Var.shares.of.loadings.param[5]   ## ############################################################## ## Figure 6: ## ############################################################## scl <- 1 par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) matplot(coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Common.factors[, 1] %*% t(coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Ind.loadings.param[,    1]), type = "l", main = "Variance of time-varying indiv. effects
 in direction of the 1. common factor",    xlab = "Time", ylab = "", cex.main = scl, cex.lab = scl, cex.axis = scl) matplot(coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Common.factors[, 2] %*% t(coef(Cigar2.KSS)$Ind.loadings.param[,    2]), type = "l", main = "Variance of time-varying indiv. effects
 in direction of the 2. common factor",    xlab = "Time", ylab = "", cex.main = scl, cex.lab = scl, cex.axis = scl) par(mfrow = c(1, 1))

title: Cigarette Consumption — Cigar
text: Baltagi, Badi H. (2001) Econometric Analysis Panel Data, 2nd ed., John Wiley Sons. Baltagi, B.H.  D. Levin (1992) “Cigarette taxation: Raising revenues reducing consumption”, Structural Changes Economic Dynamics, 3, 321--335. Baltagi, B.H., J.M. Griffin  W. Xiong (2000) “  pool pool: Homogeneous versus heterogeneous estimators   applied cigarette demand”, Review Economics   Statistics, 82, 117--126.

title: Cigarette Consumption — Cigar
code:
data(Cigar) ## Panel-Dimensions: N <- 46 T <- 30  ## Dependent variable:    ## Cigarette-Sales per Capita   l.Consumption    <- log(matrix(Cigar$sales, T,N))  ## Independent variables:    ## Consumer Price Index   cpi        <- matrix(Cigar$cpi, T,N)    ## Real Price per Pack of Cigarettes    l.Price    <- log(matrix(Cigar$price, T,N)/cpi)    ## Real Disposable Income per Capita     l.Income   <- log(matrix(Cigar$ndi,   T,N)/cpi)   #################### ## Plot the data  ## ####################  par(mfrow=c(1,3)) ## Dependent variable matplot(l.Consumption, main="Log's of Cigarette -Sales
per Capita",         type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="") ## Independent variables matplot(l.Price, main="Log's of Real-Prices of
Cigarettes per Pack",         type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="") matplot(l.Income, main="Log's of Real Disposable Income
per Capita",         type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="")  par(mfrow=c(1,1))

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
text: Estimation Panel Data Models Interactive Fixed Effects.

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
code: Eup(formula,     additive.effects = c("none", "individual", "time", "twoways"),     dim.criterion    = c("PC1", "PC2", "PC3", "BIC3","IC1", "IC2" , "IC3",                          "IPC1", "IPC2", "IPC3"),     d.max            = NULL,     sig2.hat         = NULL,     factor.dim       = NULL,     double.iteration = TRUE,     start.beta       = NULL,     max.iteration    = 500,     convergence      = 1e-6,     restrict.mode    = c("restrict.factors", "restrict.loadings"),     ...)

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
text: formula object class 'formula' arguments matrices. number rows equal temporal dimension number columns equal number individuals. details model specification given 'Details'. additive.effects Type Data Transformations: "none": transformation "individual": within transformation "time": transformation "twoways": twoways transformation dim.criterion dimensionality criterion used factor.dim left unspecified. default criterion "PC1" . d.max Maximal dimension used dimensionality-criteria Bai     (2009). default (d.max=NULL) yields internal selection     d.max. sig2.hat squared standard deviation error-term required computation dimensionality criteria. user can specify instead d.max. default (sig2.hat=NULL) yields internal estimation. factor.dim Dimension Factor-Structure, pre-specified     user. default (factor.dim=NULL) yields internal estimation. double.iteration logical. FALSE update factor dimension d done simultaneously remaining model parameters without alternating inner outer iteration. may speed computations, convergence less stable default setting. start.beta allows user give vector starting values slope parameters. max.iteration controls maximum number iterations. default '500'. convergence Convergence condition estimators. default '1e-6'. restrict.mode Type Restriction Factor-Structure: "restrict.factors": Factors restricted       euclidean norm 1. "restrict.loadings": Factor-Loadings restricted       euclidean norm 1.  ... Additional arguments passed low level functions.

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
text: 'Eup' function estimate equidistant panel data models unobserved   multiple time varying individual effects. considered model given   \($Y_{}= \sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j}     X_{itj}+ v_{} + \epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\)   individual time trends, v_it, assumed come finite dimensional factor model:     \($v_{}=\sum_{l=1}^d\lambda_{il}f_{lt},\quad \lambda_{il}, f_{lt} \	R.$\) formula Usual 'formula'-object. wish 	  estimate model without intercept use '-1' 	  formula-specification. Variable given 	  TxN-matrix. Missing values allowed. additive.effects "none": data transformed, except subtraction overall mean, model estimated intercept. assumed model can written 	    \($Y_{}= \mu + \sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+v_{}+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. "individual": "within"-model,  	    assumes time-constant individual effects, 	    alpha_i, besides individual time trends v_it. 	    model can written 	    \($Y_{}= \mu +\alpha_{} + \sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+v _{} + \epsilon_{} \quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. "time": ""-model, assumes 	    common time trend (individuals), theta_t. 	    model can written 	    \($Y_{}=\mu+ \theta_t + \sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. "twoways": "twoways"-model ("within" & 	    ""), assumes time-constant 	    individual effects, alpha_i, common time trend, 	    theta_t. model can written 	    \($Y_{}=\mu+ \alpha_{} + \theta_t +\sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+\tau_i+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. Inferences slope parameters can obtained using method summary(). type correlation heteroskedasticity idiosyncratic errors can specified choosing corresponding number argument error.type = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8) summary(), 1: indicates presence ..d. errors, 2: indicates presence cross-section heteroskedasticity  \($n/T \0$\), 3: indicates presence  cross-section correlation heteroskedasticity \($n/T \0$\), 4: indicates presence  heteroskedasticity time dimension \($T/n \0$\), 5: indicates presence  correlation heteroskedasticity time dimension \($T/n \0$\), 6: indicates presence  time cross-section dimensions \($T/n^2 \$\) \($n/T^2 \0$\), 7: indicates presence  time cross-section dimensions \($n/T \c > 0$\), 8: indicates presence  correlation heteroskedasticity time cross-section dimensions \($n/T \c > 0$\). default 1.  presence serial correlations 	(cases 5 8), kernel weights required estimating 	long-run covariance  can externally specified given 	vector weights argument kernel.weights. 	default, function uses internally linearly decreasing 	weights Newey West (1987) truncation lower 	integer part \($min(\sqrt{n},\sqrt{T})$\). case 7 8 chosen, method summary() calculates realization bias corrected estimators gives appropriate inference. bias corrected coefficients can called using method coef() object produced summary().

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
text: 'Eup' returns object 'class' '"Eup"' containing       following components:  dat.matrix: Whole data set stored within 	  (N*T)x(p+1)-Matrix, P number independent 	  variables without intercept. formula: returns used formula object. dat.dim: Vector length 3: c(T,N,p) slope.para: Beta-parameters names: Names dependent independent variables. .intercept: logical.Used intercept formula?: TRUE FALSE additive.effects: Additive effect type. One : "none","individual","time", "twoways". Intercept: Intercept-parameter. Tacks value 0 specified model. Add.Ind.Eff:  Estimated values additive individual effects. additive individual effects specified model, function returns vector zeros. Add.Tim.Eff:  Estimated values additive time effects. effects specified model, function returns vector zeros. unob.factors:  Txd-matrix estimated unobserved common 	  factors, 'd' number used factors. ind.loadings:  Nxd-matrix loadings parameters. unob.fact.stru:  TxN-matrix estimated factor 	  structure. column represents estimated individual unobserved time trend. used.dim: Used dimension 'd' calculate factor structure. proposed.dim: Indicates whether user specified factor dimension . optimal.dim: optimal dimension calculated internally. factor.dim:  user-specified factor dimension. Default NULL d.max:  maximum number factors used estimate optimal dimension. dim.criterion:  used dimensionality criterion. OvMeans: vector contains overall means observed variables (Y X). ColMean:  matrix contains column means observed variables (Y X). RowMean:  matrix contains row means observed variables (Y X). max.iteration:  maximum number iterations. default '500'. convergence: convergence condition. default '1e-6'. start.beta: vector user-specified starting values estimation beta-parameters. Default NULL. Nbr.iteration:  Number iterations required computation. fitted.values:  Fitted values. orig.Y:  Original values dependent variable. residuals:  Original values dependent variable. sig2.hat.dim: user-specified variance estimator errors. Default NULL. sig2.hat:  Estimated variance error term. degrees..freedom: Degrees freedom residuals. call

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
text: Bai, J., 2009 “Panel data models interactive fixed       effects”, Econometrica Bada, O. Kneip, ., 2014  “Parameter Cascading Panel Models Unknown Number Unobserved Factors: Application Credit Spread Puzzle”, Computational Statistics \& Data Analysis (forthcoming)

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
text: Oualid Bada

title: Eup-Routine — Eup
code: ## See the example in 'help(Cigar)' in order to take a look at the ## data set 'Cigar'  ########## ## DATA ## ##########  data(Cigar) ## Panel-Dimensions: N <- 46 T <- 30 ## Dependent variable:   ## Cigarette-Sales per Capita   d.l.Consumption    <- diff(log(matrix(Cigar$sales, T,N))) ## Independent variables:   ## Consumer Price Index   cpi        <- matrix(Cigar$cpi, T,N)   ## Real Price per Pack of Cigarettes    d.l.Price  <- diff(log(matrix(Cigar$price, T,N)/cpi))   ## Real Disposable Income per Capita     d.l.Income    <- diff(log(matrix(Cigar$ndi,   T,N)/cpi))    ## Estimation: Eup.fit      <- Eup(d.l.Consumption~d.l.Price+d.l.Income) (Eup.fit.sum <- summary(Eup.fit)) #> Call: #> Eup.default(formula = d.l.Consumption ~ d.l.Price + d.l.Income) #>  #> Residuals: #>       Min        1Q    Median        3Q       Max  #> -0.146000 -0.013900  0.000303  0.014000  0.093700  #>  #>  #>  Slope-Coefficients: #>             Estimate  Std.Err Z value    Pr(>z)     #> (Intercept) -0.00786  0.00328   -2.40    0.0165 *   #> d.l.Price   -0.32500  0.02240  -14.50 < 2.2e-16 *** #> d.l.Income   0.17400  0.03570    4.87  1.09e-06 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Additive Effects Type:  none   #>  #> Dimension of the Unobserved Factors: 5   #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.02788 on 956 degrees of freedom,   #> R-squared: 0.7039   ## Plot the components of the estimated individual effects  plot(Eup.fit.sum)

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
text: Estimation Panel Data Models Heterogeneous Time Trends

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
code: KSS(formula,     additive.effects = c("none", "individual", "time", "twoways"),     consult.dim.crit = FALSE,     d.max            = NULL,     sig2.hat         = NULL,     factor.dim       = NULL,     level            = 0.01,     spar             = NULL,     CV               = FALSE,     convergence      = 1e-6,     restrict.mode    = c("restrict.factors","restrict.loadings"), ...)

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
text: formula object class 'formula'. additive.effects Type Data Transformations: "none": transformation "individual": within transformation "time": transformation "twoways": twoways transformation consult.dim.crit logical. consult.dim.crit FALSE (default) 	factor.dim NULL: 	dimensionality criterion Kneip, Sickles & Song 2012 	used. consult.dim.crit TRUE 	factor.dim NULL: 	implemented dimensionality criteria implemented 	function OptDim() computed user 	select one proposed dimension via GUI. d.max maximal dimension needed     dimensionality-criteria implemented function     OptDim(). default (d.max=NULL) yields internal     selection d.max. sig2.hat Standard deviation error-term. default     (sig2.hat=NULL) yields internal     estimation sig2.hat. factor.dim Dimension Factor-Structure. default     (factor.dim=NULL) yields internal     estimation factor.dim. level Significance-level Dimensionality-Criterion Kneip,     Sickles & Song 2012. spar Smoothing parameter spline smoothing     residuals. (spar=NULL) (default) CV=FALSE     spar determined via generalized cross validation (GCV). CV logical. Selects procedure determination     smoothing parameter spar. CV=FALSE (default) spar=NULL: 	smoothing parameter spar determined GCV. CV=TRUE spar=NULL:       smoothing parameter spar determined Leave-one-      cross validation (CV). convergence Convergence criterion CV-optimization     smoothing parameter spar. Default     convergence=1e-6. restrict.mode Type Restriction Factor-Structure: "restrict.factors": Factors restricted       euclidean norm 1. "restrict.loadings": Factor-Loadings restricted       euclidean norm 1. ... Additional arguments passed low level functions.

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
text: 'KSS' function estimate panel data models unobserved   heterogeneous time trends v_i(t). considered model Kneip,   Sickles & Song (2012) given   \($Y_{}=\theta_{t}+\sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j}     X_{itj}+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\)       individual time trends, v_i(t), assumed come       finite dimensional factor model       \($v_i(t)=\sum_{l=1}^d\lambda_{il}f_l(t),\quad\lambda_{il}\	R,\quad f_l\L^2[0,T].$\)       unobserved functions v_i(t) can interpreted smooth       functions continuous argument t, well stochastic       processes discrete argument t. formula Usual 'formula'-object. wish 	  estimate model without intercept use '-1' 	  formula-specification. Variable given 	  TxN-matrix. Missing values allowed. additive.effects "none": data transformed, except 	    eventually subtraction overall mean; model 	    estimated intercept. assumed model can written 	    \($Y_{}=\mu+\sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. "individual": "within"-model,  	    assumes time-constant individual effects, 	    tau_i, besides individual time trends v_i(t). 	    model can written 	    \($Y_{}=\mu+\sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+v_i(t)+\alpha_{}+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. "time": ""-model, assumes 	    common (individuals) time trend, beta_0(t). 	    model can written 	    \($Y_{}=\mu+\theta_{t}+\sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula. "twoways": "twoways"-model ("within" & 	    ""), assumes time-constant 	    individual effects, tau_i, common time trend, 	    beta_0(t). model can written 	    \($Y_{}=\mu+\theta_{t}+\sum_{j=1}^P\beta_{j} 	      X_{itj}+\alpha_i+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad =1,\dots,n; t=1,\dots,T.$\) 	    parameter 'mu' set zero '-1' used formula.

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
text: 'KSS' returns object 'class' '"KSS"'. object class '"KSS"' list containing least       following components:  dat.matrix: Whole data set stored within 	  (N*T)x(p+1)-Matrix, P number independent 	  variables without intercept. dat.dim: Vector length 3: c(T,N,p) slope.para: Beta-parameters beta.V: Covariance matrix beta-parameters. names: Names dependent independent variables. .intercept: Used intercept formula?: TRUE FALSE additive.effects: Additive effect type. One : "none","individual","time", "twoways". Intercept: Intercept-parameter Add.Ind.Eff: Estimated values additive individual effects. Add.Tim.Eff: Estimated values additive time effects. unob.factors: Txd-matrix estimated unobserved common 	  factors, 'd' number used factors. ind.loadings: Nxd-matrix loadings parameters. unob.fact.stru: TxN-matrix estimated factor 	  structure. column represents estimated individual unobserved time trend. used.dim: Used dimensionality factor structure. optimal.dim: List proposed dimensionalities. fitted.values: Fitted values. orig.Y: Original values dependent variable. residuals: Residuals sig2.hat: Estimated variance error term. degrees..freedom: Degrees freedom residuals. call

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
text: Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., Song, W., 2012 “New Panel Data       Treatment Heterogeneity Time Trends”, Econometric Theory

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
text: Dominik Liebl

title: KSS-Routine — KSS
code: ## See the example in 'help(Cigar)' in order to take a look at the ## data set Cigar  ########## ## DATA ## ##########  data(Cigar) ## Panel-Dimensions: N <- 46 T <- 30 ## Dependent variable:   ## Cigarette-Sales per Capita   l.Consumption    <- log(matrix(Cigar$sales, T,N)) ## Independent variables:   ## Consumer Price Index   cpi        <- matrix(Cigar$cpi, T,N)   ## Real Price per Pack of Cigarettes    l.Price  <- log(matrix(Cigar$price, T,N)/cpi)   ## Real Disposable Income per Capita     l.Income    <- log(matrix(Cigar$ndi,   T,N)/cpi)  ## Estimation: KSS.fit      <- KSS(l.Consumption~l.Price+l.Income, CV=TRUE) #> Progress: CV-Optimization is running. #> ......... #>  CV-Optimization converged. #> Dimensions of factors: 30 6  #> Dimensions of loadings: 46 6  #> Dimensions of TR.Y.mat: 30 46  #> Dimensions of factor.stract: 30 46  (KSS.fit.sum <- summary(KSS.fit)) #> Call: #> KSS.default(formula = l.Consumption ~ l.Price + l.Income, CV = TRUE) #>  #> Residuals: #>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max  #>  -0.12  -0.01   0.00   0.01   0.13  #>  #>  #>  Slope-Coefficients: #>             Estimate StdErr z.value Pr(>z)     #> (Intercept)   4.7900 0.1850    25.9 <2e-16 *** #> l.Price       0.0000 0.0232     0.0      1     #> l.Income      0.0000 0.0400     0.0      1     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Additive Effects Type:  none   #>  #> Used Dimension of the Unobserved Factors: 6   #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.000852 on 921 degrees of freedom  #> R-squared: 0.989  plot(KSS.fit.sum)

what: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
text: Functions Estimation Factor Dimension

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
code: OptDim(Obj,         criteria = c("PC1", "PC2", "PC3", "BIC3",                      "IC1", "IC2", "IC3",                      "IPC1","IPC2", "IPC3",                      "ABC.IC1", "ABC.IC2",                      "KSS.C",                      "ED",  "ER",  "GR"),        standardize = FALSE,        d.max,        sig2.hat,        spar,        level = 0.01,         c.grid = seq(0, 5, length.out = 128),        T.seq, n.seq)

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
text: Obj function requires either Txn matrix object class "`Eup"' "`KSS"'. criteria character vector contains desired criteria used. left unspecified, function returns result 16 criteria. standardize logical. TRUE input variable standardized. Default FALSE. d.max Maximal dimension used dimensionality-criteria Bai     (2009). default (d.max=NULL) yields internal selection     d.max. sig2.hat squared standard deviation error-term required computation dimensionality criteria. user can specify instead d.max. default (sig2.hat=NULL) yields internal estimation. spar Smoothing parameter used calculate criterion Kneip, Sickles, Song (2012). default NULL, leads internal computation. level significance level used criterion Kneip, Sickles, Song (2012). default 0.01. c.grid Required computing "ABC.IC1" "ABC.IC2". specifies grid interval scaling parameter penalty terms "ABC.IC1" "ABC.IC2" calibrated. Default c.grid  =seq(0, 5, length.= 128). T.seq Required computing "ABC.IC1" "ABC.IC2". can vector containing different dimensions T integer indicating length sequence considered calibrating  "ABC.IC1" "ABC.IC2". left unspecified, function determines internally sequence form seq((T-C), T), C square root min{T,900}. n.seq Required computing "ABC.IC1" "ABC.IC2". can vector containing different dimensions n integer indicating length sequence considered calibrating  "ABC.IC1" "ABC.IC2". left unspecified, function determines internally sequence form seq((n-D), n), D square root min{n,900}.

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
text: function 'OptDim' allows comparison optimal factor dimensions obtained different panel criteria (total 13). criteria adjusted panel data diverging T N.

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
text: 'OptDim' returns object 'class' '"OptDim"' containing list       following components: criteria: name criteria specified user. PC1: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. PC2: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. PC3: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. IC1: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max. IC2: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max. IC3: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max. IPC1: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. IPC2: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. IPC3: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. KSS.C: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max / sig2.hat. ED: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max. ER: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max. GR: specified criteria table returned optimal dimension, empirical standard deviation residuals, informations required internally criterion, d.max. summary: table (matrix form) containing estimated dimensions obtained specified criteria. BaiNgC: logical vector required internal computations. BaiC: logical vector required internal computations. KSSC: logical vector required internal computations. OnatC: logical vector required internal computations. RHC: logical vector required internal computations. obj: argument 'Obj' given function OptDim(). cl: Object mode "call".

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
text: Ahn, S. C., Horenstein, . R. 2013 “Eigenvalue ratio test number factors”, Econometrica Bai, J., 2009 “Panel data models interactive fixed       effects”, Econometrica Bai, J. 2004 “Estimating cross-section common stochastic trends nonstationary data”,  Journal Econometrics Bai, J., Ng, S. 2009 “Determining number factors approximated factor models”, Econometrica Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., Song, W., 2012 “New Panel Data       Treatment Heterogeneity Time Trends”, Econometric Theory Onatski, . 2010 “Determining number factors empirical distribution eigenvalues”, Review Economics Statistics

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
text: Oualid Bada

title: Estimation of the Factor Dimension — OptDim
code: ## See the example in 'help(Cigar)' in order to take a look at the ## data set 'Cigar'  ########## ## DATA ## ##########  data(Cigar) N <- 46 T <- 30   ## Data: Cigarette-Sales per Capita l.Consumption    <- log(matrix(Cigar$sales, T,N))  ## Calculation is based on the covariance matrix of l.Consumption  OptDim(l.Consumption) #> Call: OptDim.default(Obj = l.Consumption) #>  #> --------- #> Criterion of Kneip, Sickles, and Song (2012): #>  #>   KSS.C #>       6 #>  #> --------- #> Criteria of Bai and Ng (2002): #>  #>   PC1 PC2 PC3 BIC3 IC1 IC2 IC3 #>     5   5   5    4   5   5   5 #>  #> -------- #> Criteria of Ahn and Horenstein (2013): #>  #>   ER GR #>    3  2 #>  #> --------- #> Criteria of Bai (2004): #>  #>   IPC1 IPC2 IPC3 #>      3    3    2 #>  #> --------- #> Criterion of Onatski (2009): #>  #>   ED #>    4 #>  #> --------- #> ABC calibration of IC1 and IC2 (Alessi et al. (2010)): #>  #>   ABC.IC1 ABC.IC2 #>         4       4  ## Calculation is based on the correlation matrix of l.Consumption  OptDim(l.Consumption, standardize = TRUE) #> Call: OptDim.default(Obj = l.Consumption, standardize = TRUE) #>  #> --------- #> Criterion of Kneip, Sickles, and Song (2012): #>  #>   KSS.C #>       6 #>  #> --------- #> Criteria of Bai and Ng (2002): #>  #>   PC1 PC2 PC3 BIC3 IC1 IC2 IC3 #>     5   5   5    4   5   5   5 #>  #> -------- #> Criteria of Ahn and Horenstein (2013): #>  #>   ER GR #>    3  3 #>  #> --------- #> Criteria of Bai (2004): #>  #>   IPC1 IPC2 IPC3 #>      3    3    2 #>  #> --------- #> Criterion of Onatski (2009): #>  #>   ED #>    4 #>  #> --------- #> ABC calibration of IC1 and IC2 (Alessi et al. (2010)): #>  #>   ABC.IC1 ABC.IC2 #>         4       4  ## Display the magnitude of the eigenvalues in percentage of the total variance  plot(OptDim(l.Consumption))

what: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
text: Panel-Data Sets : time-index : t=1,...,T=30 individual-index : =1,...,N=60 panel-data set polynomial factor structure (3 common   factors) exogenous regressors.

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
text: list containing : Y dependent variable N*T-vector X1 first regressor N*T-vector X2 second regressor N*T-vector CF.1 first (unobserved) common factor: \($CF.1(t)=1$\) CF.2 second (unobserved) common factor: \($CF.2(t)=\frac{t}{T}$\) CF.3 thrid (unobserved) common factor: \($CF.3(t)=\left(\frac{t}{T}\right)^2$\)  Remark: time-index t running faster     individual-index e.g. Y_it ordered :     \($Y_{11},Y_{12},\ldots,Y_{1T},Y_{21},Y_{22},\ldots$\)

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
text: panel-data set DPG1 simulated according simulation-study   Kneip, Sickles & Song (2012):   \($Y_{}=\beta_{1}X_{it1}+\beta_{2}X_{it2}+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad     =1,\dots,n;\quad     t=1,\dots,T$\)   -Slope parameters:   \($\beta_{1}=\beta_{2}=0.5$\) -Time varying individual effects second order polynomials:   \($v_i(t)=\theta_{i0}+\theta_{i1}\frac{t}{T}+\theta_{i2}\left(\frac{t}{T}\right)^2$\)   theta_i1, theta_i1, theta_i1 iid N(0,4) Regressors X_it=(X_it1,X_it2)' simulated bivariate VAR model:   \($X_{}=R X_{,t-1}+\eta_{}\quad\textrm{}\quad   R=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0.4&0.05\\0.05&0.4\end{array}\right)\quad\textrm{}\quad   \eta_{}\sim N(0,I_2)$\) simulation, N regressor-series   \($(X_{1i1},X_{2i1})',\dots,(X_{1iT},X_{2iT})'$\)   additionally shifted three different   mean-value-clusters. every third N regressor-series   fluctuates around following mean-values   \($\mu_1=(5,5)',\;\mu_2=(7.5,7.5)',\textrm{ }\;\mu_3=(10,10)'$\) Panel-Data Set regressors exogenous. See Kneip, Sickles & Song (2012) details.

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
text: Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., Song, W., 2012 “New Panel Data       Treatment Heterogneity Time Trends”, Econometric Theory

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
text: Dominik Liebl

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and exogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP1
code: data(DGP1)  ## Dimensions N    <- 60 T    <- 30  ## Observed Variables Y    <- matrix(DGP1$Y,  nrow=T,ncol=N) X1   <- matrix(DGP1$X1, nrow=T,ncol=N) X2   <- matrix(DGP1$X2, nrow=T,ncol=N)  ## Unobserved common factors CF.1 <- DGP1$CF.1[1:T] CF.2 <- DGP1$CF.2[1:T] CF.3 <- DGP1$CF.3[1:T]  ## Take a look at the simulated data set DGP1: par(mfrow=c(2,2)) matplot(Y,  type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="Depend Variable") matplot(X1, type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="First Regressor") matplot(X2, type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="Second Regressor") ## Usually unobserved common factors: matplot(matrix(c(CF.1,                  CF.2,                  CF.3), nrow=T,ncol=3),         type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="Unobserved Common Factors")  par(mfrow=c(1,1))  ## Estimation: KSS.fit      <-KSS(Y~-1+X1+X2) #> Dimensions of factors: 30 2  #> Dimensions of loadings: 60 2  #> Dimensions of TR.Y.mat: 30 60  #> Dimensions of factor.stract: 30 60  (KSS.fit.sum <-summary(KSS.fit)) #> Call: #> KSS.default(formula = Y ~ -1 + X1 + X2) #>  #> Residuals: #>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max  #>  -3.70  -0.84   0.00   0.82   4.77  #>  #>  #>  Slope-Coefficients: #>    Estimate StdErr z.value Pr(>z) #> X1   0.0000 0.0315       0      1 #> X2   0.0000 0.0307       0      1 #>  #> Additive Effects Type:  none   #>  #> Used Dimension of the Unobserved Factors: 2   #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.64 on 1618 degrees of freedom  #> R-squared: 0.945   plot(KSS.fit.sum)

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2
Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2
text: data frame containing : Y dependent variable N*T-vector X1 first regressor N*T-vector X2 second regressor N*T-vector CF.1 first (unobserved) common factor: \($CF.1(t)=1$\) CF.2 second (unobserved) common factor: \($CF.2(t)=\frac{t}{T}$\) CF.3 thrid (unobserved) common factor: \($CF.3(t)=\left(\frac{t}{T}\right)^2$\)  Remark: time-index t running "faster"     individual-index e.g. Y_it ordered :     \($Y_{11},Y_{12},\ldots,Y_{1T},Y_{21},Y_{22},\ldots$\)

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2
text: panel-data set DPG2 simulated according simulation-study   Kneip, Sickles & Song (2012):   \($Y_{}=\beta_{1}X_{it1}+\beta_{2}X_{it2}+v_i(t)+\epsilon_{}\quad     =1,\dots,n;\quad     t=1,\dots,T$\)   -Slope parameters:   \($\beta_{1}=\beta_{2}=0.5$\) -Time varying individual effects second order polynomials:   \($v_i(t)=\theta_{i0}+\theta_{i1}\frac{t}{T}+\theta_{i2}\left(\frac{t}{T}\right)^2$\)   theta_i1, theta_i1, theta_i1 iid N(0,4) Regressors X_it=(X_it1,X_it2)' simulated bivariate VAR model:   \($X_{}=R X_{,t-1}+\eta_{}\quad\textrm{}\quad   R=\left(\begin{array}{cc}0.4&0.05\\0.05&0.4\end{array}\right)\quad\textrm{}\quad   \eta_{}\sim N(0,I_2)$\) simulation, N regressor-series   \($(X_{1i1},X_{2i1})',\dots,(X_{1iT},X_{2iT})'$\)   additionally shifted three different   mean-value-clusters. every third N regressor-series   fluctuates around following mean-values   \($\mu_1=(5,5)',\;\mu_2=(7.5,7.5)',\textrm{ }\;\mu_3=(10,10)'$\) Panel-Data Set regressor X_it2 made endogenous   re-definition:   \($X_{it2}:=X_{it2}+0.5 v_i(t)$\) See Kneip, Sickles & Song (2012) details.

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2
text: Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., Song, W., 2012 “New Panel Data       Treatment Heterogneity Time Trends”, Econometric Theory

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2
text: Dominik Liebl

title: Simulated Panel-Data Set with Polynomial Factor Structure and endogenous regressors. — Simulated Data for the KSS-Model: DGP2
code: data(DGP2)  ## Dimensions N    <- 60 T    <- 30  ## Observed Variables Y    <- matrix(DGP2$Y,  nrow=T,ncol=N) X1   <- matrix(DGP2$X1, nrow=T,ncol=N) X2   <- matrix(DGP2$X2, nrow=T,ncol=N)  ## Unobserved common factors CF.1 <- DGP2$CF.1[1:T] CF.2 <- DGP2$CF.2[1:T] CF.3 <- DGP2$CF.3[1:T]  ## Take a look at the simulated data set DGP2: par(mfrow=c(2,2)) matplot(Y,  type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="Depend Variable") matplot(X1, type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="First Regressor") matplot(X2, type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="Second Regressor") ## Usually unobserved common factors: matplot(matrix(c(CF.1,                  CF.2,                  CF.3), nrow=T,ncol=3),         type="l", xlab="Time", ylab="", main="Unobserved Common Factors")  par(mfrow=c(1,1))  ## Esimation KSS.fit      <- KSS(Y~-1+X1+X2) #> Dimensions of factors: 30 2  #> Dimensions of loadings: 60 2  #> Dimensions of TR.Y.mat: 30 60  #> Dimensions of factor.stract: 30 60  (KSS.fit.sum <- summary(KSS.fit)) #> Call: #> KSS.default(formula = Y ~ -1 + X1 + X2) #>  #> Residuals: #>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max  #>  -3.70  -0.84   0.02   0.84   4.77  #>  #>  #>  Slope-Coefficients: #>    Estimate StdErr z.value Pr(>z) #> X1   0.0000 0.0318       0      1 #> X2   0.0000 0.0307       0      1 #>  #> Additive Effects Type:  none   #>  #> Used Dimension of the Unobserved Factors: 2   #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.67 on 1618 degrees of freedom  #> R-squared: 0.96   plot(KSS.fit.sum)

what: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
title: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
text: Tests check model specifications

title: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
text: obj1  obj2 left unspecified specification test       proposed Kneip, Sickles, Song (2012) computed.       case obj1 can object class 'KSS'       'Eup'. given KSS- Eup-model needs unspecified       factor dimensions (factor.dim=NULL). See also Details. obj2 specified object class       'Eup' Hausman-type test proposed Bai (2009)       computed, compares model obj1 model       obj2. Hausman-type test Bai applies       'Eup'-objects . See also Details. obj2 object class 'Eup'. obj2 left     unspecified test proposed Kneip, Sickles, Song (2012)     computed. level significance level.

title: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
text: function equipped two types specification-tests: first specification-tests Hausman-type test       proposed Bai (2009), computed obj1 well       obj2 specified 'Eup'-objects. case       model given arguments obj1 obj2       compared . Note test assumes       (unobserved) true factor dimension lower equal 2; see       Section 9 Bai (2009) details.      Given assumption one unobserved common factor: Null-Hypothesis: 'unobserved common factor 	  classical individual time effect'. Alternative-Hypothesis: 'unobserved common factor 	  arbitrary process'. Null-Hypothesis: 'two unobserved common factors classical 	  twoways effects'. Alternative-Hypothesis: 'two unobserved common factors 	  arbitrary processes'. second specification-test tests existence additional       factor structure beyond classical additive effects model; suggested       Kneip, Sickles, Song (2012), applied       obj1 specified obj2 left unspecified.       test can used 'Eup'-objects well       'KSS'-objects. Null-Hypothesis: 'unobserved common factors       beyond classical individual, time,       twoways effects'. Alternative-Hypothesis: 'additional unobserved 	  common factors'.

title: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
text: Bai, J., 2009 “Panel data models interactive fixed       effects”, Econometrica Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., Song, W., 2012 “New Panel Data       Treatment Heterogeneity Time Trends”, Econometric Theory

title: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
text: Oualid Bada, Dominik Liebl

title: Tests to check the model specifications — checkSpecif
code: ## See the example in 'help(Cigar)' in order to take a look at the ## data set 'Cigar'  ########## ## DATA ## ##########  data(Cigar) ## Panel-Dimensions: N <- 46 T <- 30 ## Dependent variable:   ## Cigarette-Sales per Capita   l.Consumption      <- log(matrix(Cigar$sales, T,N))   d.l.Consumption    <- diff(l.Consumption) ## Independent variables:   ## Consumer Price Index   cpi           <- matrix(Cigar$cpi, T,N)   ## Real Price per Pack of Cigarettes    l.Price       <- log(matrix(Cigar$price, T,N)/cpi)   d.l.Price     <- diff(l.Price)   ## Real Disposable Income per Capita     l.Income      <- log(matrix(Cigar$ndi,   T,N)/cpi)   d.l.Income    <- diff(l.Income)  ##################################################################### ## Testing the Sufficiency of a classical 'twoways' effects model: ## ## Hausman-type Test of Bai (2009)                                 ## #####################################################################  ## Model under the null Hypothesis: twoways.obj <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income,   factor.dim = 0, additive.effects = "twoways")  ## Model under the alternative Hypothesis: not.twoways.obj <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income,   factor.dim = 2, additive.effects = "none")  ########### ## Test: ## ###########  ## (This test returns an error message, since the (unobserved) true ## factor dimension is probably greater than 2.) if (FALSE) { checkSpecif(obj1 = twoways.obj, obj2 = not.twoways.obj, level = 0.01) }  ##################################################################### ## Testing the Existence of additional (unobserved) common Factors ## ## Specification Test of Kneip, Sickles, and Song (2012)           ## #####################################################################  ## For the model of Bai (2009): Eup.obj <- Eup(d.l.Consumption ~ -1 + d.l.Price + d.l.Income,      additive.effects = "twoways")  ## Test: checkSpecif(Eup.obj, level = 0.01) #> ---------------------------------------------- #> Testing the Presence of Interactive Effects #> Test of Kneip, Sickles, and Song (2012) #> ---------------------------------------------- #> H0: The factor dimension is equal to 0. #>  #> Test-Statistic        p-value    crit.-value     sig.-level  #>          13.29           0.00           2.33           0.01   ## For the model of Kneip, Sickles, and Song (2012): KSS.obj <- KSS(l.Consumption ~ -1 + l.Price + l.Income,      additive.effects = "twoways") #> Dimensions of factors: 30 5  #> Dimensions of loadings: 46 5  #> Dimensions of TR.Y.mat: 30 46  #> Dimensions of factor.stract: 30 46   ## Test: checkSpecif(KSS.obj, level = 0.01) #> ---------------------------------------------- #> Testing the Presence of Interactive Effects #> Test of Kneip, Sickles, and Song (2012) #> ---------------------------------------------- #> H0: The factor dimension is equal to 0. #>  #> Test-Statistic        p-value    crit.-value     sig.-level  #>      104229.55           0.00           2.33           0.01

what: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends — phtt-package
title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends — phtt-package
text: R-package phtt provides estimation procedures panel data   large dimensions n, T, general forms unobservable   heterogeneous effects. Particularly, estimation procedures   Bai (2009) Kneip, Sickles, Song (2012),   complement one another well: models assume unobservable   heterogeneous effects factor structure. method Bai   (2009) assumes factors stationary, whereas method   Kneip et al. (2012) allows factors   non-stationary. Additionally, phtt package provides wide range   dimensionality criteria order estimate number   unobserved factors simultaneously remaining model   parameters.

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends — phtt-package
text: Oualid Bada,    Dominik Liebl

title: Panel Data Analysis with Heterogeneous Time Trends — phtt-package
text: Kneip, ., Sickles, R. C., Song, W., 2012 “new panel data       treatment heterogeneity time trends”, Econometric Theory Bai, J., 2009 “Panel data models interactive fixed       effects”, Econometrica
